ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
What is your overall rating of the primary instructor?
The primary instructor's sensitivity to students and ability to provide students with adequate feedback was:

narratives.question_text: Indicate the total number of hours per week (outside the classroom) you spent on this course:
comments: first half 0-3the second hafl 5-10
0-8 hours, very little early in the semester, a lot later in the semester.
5-6 hours
4 hours
1-2hrs per week until reading period where he demanded 10-12hrs per week
Not as much in the beginning of the semester, but a lot more near the end (anywhere from 8 to 20 per week)

narratives.question_text: Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved?
comments: There was a lot of memorization and very little application until the end of class. It would have been easier to understand terms if cases were spread throughout the semester instead of solely at the end.
It was a very interesting class. Sometimes it was difficult to see the forest amongst the trees, but the last section of the class really tied everything together.
It is a good class and teaches you some basic idea in risk assessment.
informative

This course provides a strong introduction to cancer and noncancer risk assessment, and applies these principles in several small discussions, leading up to a final debate. The debate is a critical component of the course, testing students' abilities to adequately synthesize and articulate concepts learned.

In the beginning, I wasn't sure how I felt about the class or where it was going. However, by the end of the class, looking back, I thought that the class made sense and came together for me. I think I might have preferred to get some reading earlier on that was lighter. Maybe if there is a beginner textbook for Risk assessment? I'm not sure what I'm looking for, but something to help guide the first half of the semester. In the end though, I did feel that I got a lot out of the class, and I enjoyed the MTBE debate. I'm definitely glad that I took the course.
Confusing at times. Lectures and expectations of course were very confusing and hard to figure out what the professor expects.

The two quizzes in the early part of the semester emphasize rote memorization instead of comprehension of concepts. Overall the course was worth it. Some of the assignments felt out of place though unfortunately. Course would be enhanced by the presence of a textbook.
It was a challenging class and more difficult than expected.

I did not enjoy this course because I felt like so much material was thrown at us in the beginning (which I understand was necessary in order to do what came later) and then all the work for the course was given to us at the end, which was a little overwhelming. I wish we were given examples of risk assessmentswhen we were learning the material so that we could better visualize what he was talking about. I felt very lost throughout the entire semester, and I know I am not alone in feeling that way.

This was undoubtedly the most poorly executed course I have taken at Yale, possibly including my undergraduate education. Dr. Borak immediately alerted the students that the course relied heavily on the understanding of jargon yet made no efforts to help students become accustomed to the jargon. And when the students were not able to keep up, as revealed from the classwide poor performance on the first quiz, Dr. Borak was vocally upset with us and proceeded ahead with no change in methods. Furthermore, it is ridiculous to assign students to prepare for and conduct a debate during reading week as well as prepare for a final exam. While the course requires minimal work throughout the semester, the amount of "rushed" project he forces on us at the end is not appropriate. Additionally, Dr. Borak almost refused to clarify what it was he wanted us to debate or understand for the final exam. None of us were certain if we was being intentionally difficult to understand when asked the question, "what is the topic of the debate" or if he really is incapable of answering a simple question.

A lot of the information provided and the cases we studied seemed isolated and unrelated until the end. Perhaps the class could emphasize better why we were studying specific cases and what underlying principle is important to the professor.

A very comprehensive look at Risk Assessment, both conceptually and practically.Not intuitive in the first few weeks.Concepts and sub-topics do come together well (PLUS)However the subject can be quite heavy when combined (NOT-SO-PLUS).Vocab quizzes are good for helping to encourage understanding (PLUS)But do not entirely prepare persons for theory challenge in final (NOT-SO-PLUS).

I left the class feeling like I didn't learn much. I was confused most of the semester and every other student I spoke with was in the same boat. Probably the most frustrating thing was the fact that we had to conduct a 'debate' during our reading week at the end of the semester. I think it should have been done prior to the reading week if at all, because all it did was add much more stress than there should have been. Rather than using the reading week to prepare for my other finals, I had to spend it with my group preparing for this debate which then left me a whole day and a half to study for 3 finals. The only benefit was that it did help sum up the semester of information to the point where I felt I finally almost understood the concepts. Although I wish this would have been a bit sooner in the semester so I wasn't having an "aha" moment right before the test, it at least helped me with the final.
This class taught concepts used in other classes and was very beneficial for occ med students.

narratives.question_text: Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?
comments: Instructor: Jonathan Borak  Great

Instructor: Jonathan Borak  Jonathan Borak: Incredibly knowledgeable about the subject. Encouraged us to participate in class.Cheryl Fields: A very clear lecturer. Constructive comments during presentation and debate.
Instructor: Jonathan Borak  excellent, the lectue is clear
Instructor: Jonathan Borak  informative, interesting, enthusiastic

Instructor: Jonathan Borak  Dr. Borak is an exceptional professor who devotes his time willingly to students. His lectures are very engaging, and he presents the information in a succinct fashion that is understandable for both physicians and public health students outside the realm of healthcare. Dr. Borak is always open to visits for questions or concerns at his office.

Instructor: Jonathan Borak  Jonathan is a very knowledgeable instructor. He makes a LOT of effort to meet with his students and speak with them . My one wish is that he would go through and try to explain the concepts FIRST simply, and then to use the more elevated definitions. I often felt that I wasn't sure what was being said. In reflection though, I feel very positively about the instruction. As aprofessor, Jonathan is very eager to provide feedback, and responded well to questions and encouraged class discussion and student participation with the material.
Instructor: Jonathan Borak  Very understanding and enthusiastic professor!
Instructor: Jonathan Borak  Good instructor, flexible and passionate about his students learning course concepts.
Instructor: Jonathan Borak  Very kind and knowledgeable.

Instructor: Jonathan Borak  Although I enjoyed having Dr. Borak as a professor, he could have been much clearer about what he wanted us to do when it came to assignments and projects. I felt like I never truly understood what was expected of us.

Instructor: Jonathan Borak  This was undoubtedly the most poorly executed course I have taken at Yale, possibly including my undergraduate education. Dr. Borak immediately alerted the students that the course relied heavily on the understanding of jargon yet made no efforts to help students become accustomed to the jargon. And when the students were not able to keep up, as revealed from the classwide poor performance on the first quiz, Dr. Borak was vocally upset with us and proceeded ahead with no change in methods. Furthermore, it is ridiculous to assign students to prepare for and conduct a debate during reading week as well as prepare for a final exam. While the course requires minimal work throughout the semester, the amount of "rushed" project he forces on us at the end is not appropriate. Additionally, Dr. Borak almost refused to clarify what it was he wanted us to debate or understand for the final exam. None of us were certain if we was being intentionally difficult to understand when asked the question, "what is the topic of the debate" or if he really is incapable of answering a simple question.

Instructor: Jonathan Borak  Professor provided a wealth of real world experience and provided a lot of examples and cases where he had some involvement in. The only thing I would change is to somehow emphasize more class participation. Professor Borak did encourage discussion, but understand that this is the first risk assessment class of a lot of students, and this lack of experience is going to make us hesitate to answer some of the questions for fear of being utterly wrong.

Instructor: Jonathan Borak  Very knowledgeable. Eloquent. Passionate. Humorous. Very inviting and approachable. Tries much to be available and willing to share supplementary materials.A bit intimidating though not quite insisting; could find more ways and/or means to encourage participation, given his lecture style.P.S.His TA is very engaging and fair/diplomaticin providing feedback when interacting.More interaction during actual lectures would be a plus.

Instructor: Jonathan Borak  He was very enthusiastic about the material, that was clear. I just never felt like I got a clear answer when I or anyone else would ask a question. It was almost like his answers were like a politician's in that they were very vague and didn't seem to get to the point or bottom line. This made it very difficult to understand.

Instructor: Jonathan Borak  I liked his teaching style. He was very methodical, easy to approach, and did a good job of recapping the concepts learned in prior classes. I felt at times that his instructions for assignments needed further clarification. It was helpfulto visit him at his office.

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize this course for a fellow student? Would you recommend it to another student? Why or why not?
comments: The course is very back heavy and most assignments are at the end of the semester.
Great class, but only take it if you're interested in the subject matter.
The first half of the class is easy, just listen to the lecures. It's busy in the second half due to tests, group projects and exams. It's a good introduction to the area.
I would recommend it.
I would strongly recommend this course to those interested in risk assessment.

I would recommend this class to fellow students. The class really comes together in the last third of the semester, so my advice to students would be to be patient, because the end was worth the slog to get there. I only wonder if there were some way to improve the beginning of the course.
I would not recommend this course, since its confusing what is going on and what is expected. Although the course material itself is not that bad though.
I'd recommend this course if one would like to understand the reason behind risk assessments as well as the process of conducting a risk assessment.
Would not recommend this class unless you want to do risk assessments in the future.

This was a tough course because the material was very abstract, and the instructor was not as clear as he could of been at times with what was expected of us. If it wasn't required I don't think I would have taken it.

This was undoubtedly the most poorly executed course I have taken at Yale, possibly including my undergraduate education. Dr. Borak immediately alerted the students that the course relied heavily on the understanding of jargon yet made no efforts to help students become accustomed to the jargon. And when the students were not able to keep up, as revealed from the classwide poor performance on the first quiz, Dr. Borak was vocally upset with us and proceeded ahead with no change in methods. Furthermore, it is ridiculous to assign students to prepare for and conduct a debate during reading week as well as prepare for a final exam. While the course requires minimal work throughout the semester, the amount of "rushed" project he forces on us at the end is not appropriate. Additionally, Dr. Borak almost refused to clarify what it was he wanted us to debate or understand for the final exam. None of us were certain if we was being intentionally difficult to understand when asked the question, "what is the topic of the debate" or if he really is incapable of answering a simple question.
A very comprehensive look at Risk Assessment, both conceptually and practically

The course information didn't seem to finally come together until the very end of the semester after the debate. Although I felt I finally got something out of the course in the end, this led to a very frustrating semester. However, the concepts are very important to understanding all aspects of environmental health sciences in a practical sense.
It is a much needed class for occ med students. There is no textbook but instead several readings and course lectures. Note taking and attendance is very important.
